article_title: Krugman: Assessing Obama's war on inequality
article_text:
Krugman: Assessing Obama's war on inequality Paul Krugman says Obama's new rules on OT pay will do more than most people realize to fight income inequality."

There were two big economic policy stories this week that you may have missed if you were distracted by Trumpian bombast and the yelling of the Sanders dead-enders. Each tells you a lot about both what President Barack Obama has accomplished and the stakes in this year's election.

article_metadata.description: The presumptive Republican nominee - who has already declared that he will, in fact, slash taxes on the rich, whatever he may have said in the recent past - once again declared his intention to do away with Dodd-Frank, the financial reform passed during Democrats' brief window of congressional control.  On one side, pro-labor policies led to a striking expansion of unions, which, along with the establishment of a fairly high minimum wage, helped raise wages, especially at the bottom.  Partly with higher taxes and bigger social programs, but it starts with lower inequality in market incomes, thanks in large part to high minimum wages and a labor movement representing two-thirds of workers.  That makes it an important redistributionist policy - the biggest such policy since the 1960s.  [...] between those extra Obamacare taxes and the expiration of the high-end Bush tax cuts made possible by Obama's re-election, the average federal tax rate on the top 1 percent has risen quite a lot.  [...] it's roughly back to what it was in 1979, pre-Ronald Reagan, something nobody seems to know.  Because despite what you may have heard about its ineffectuality, Dodd-Frank actually has put a substantial crimp in the ability of Wall Street to make money hand over fist.  Money talks on both sides of the aisle, but the influence of big donors hasn't prevented the current president from doing a substantial amount to narrow income gaps - and he would have done much more if he'd faced less opposition in Congress.
article_metadata.author.name: By Paul Krugman
